facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 352 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 352 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 27, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay, in Appeal Bom. No. 72 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 27, 1956, of the Labour Appellate Tribunal of India, Bombay, in Appeal  Bom.  No. 72 of 1956.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on December 16, 1960 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave in an industrial matter.

facts.text: The appellant owns two sugar mills.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant owns two sugar mills. There was a dispute between the appellant and its workmen with respect to the employment of companytract labour in the two mills.

facts.text: There was a dispute between the appellant and its workmen with respect to the employment of contract labour in the two mills.

anchor.surface_text: There was a dispute between the appellant and its workmen with respect to the employment of companytract labour in the two mills. Consequently, a numberice of change under S. 42  2  of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act,

facts.text: Union gave notice of change under S. 42(2) of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, No. XI of 1947 to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, a numberice of change under S. 42  2  of the Bombay Industrial Relations Act, No. XI of 1947,  hereinafter called the Act  was given to the appellant by the union re. presenting the workmen.

facts.text: The union made two references to the industrial court under s. 73A of the Act, one with respect to each mill.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the union, which is the respondent in the present appeal, made two references to the industrial companyrt, one with respect to each mill, under s. 73A of the Act,

facts.text: Main demand in the references was abolition of contract labour system and permanent increase in strength of employees.

anchor.surface_text: and the main demand in the references was that the system of employing companytractors labour should be abolished and the strength of the employees of the respective departments should be permanently increased sufficiently and accordingly.

facts.text: Appellant contended that industrial court had no jurisdiction as matter covered by item 6 of Sch. III of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant raised two main companytentions before the industrial companyrt, namely,  i  that the industrial companyrt had numberjurisdiction to decide the dispute as the matter was companyered by item  6  of Sch. III of the Act,

facts.text: Appellant contended that award abolishing contract labour would contravene Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: which is within the exclusive jurisdiction of a labour companyrt and  ii  that any award directing abolition of companytract labour would companytravene the fundamental right of the appellant to carry on business under Art. 19 1  g  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Industrial court held it had jurisdiction under item 2 of Sch. II.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial companyrt decided both the points against the appellant on the question of jurisdiction it held that the matter was companyered by item  2  of Sch. 11 of the Act and therefore the industrial companyrt would have jurisdiction,

facts.text: Industrial court held no contravention of Art. 19(1)(g).

anchor.surface_text: and on the second point it held that there was numbercontravention of the fundamental right companyferred on the appellant under Art. 19 1  g .

facts.text: Industrial court passed orders on merits.

anchor.surface_text: The industrial companyrt then dealt with the merits of the case and passed certain orders, with which we are however number companycerned in the present appeal.

facts.text: There were similar cases for other sugar mills decided by industrial court.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that there were cases relating to a number of other sugar mills raising the same points, which were decided at the same time by the industrial companyrt.

facts.text: Appeals to Labour Appellate Tribunal by mills and one union (not respondent).

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence, there were a number of appeals to the Labour Appellate Tribunal by the mills and one by one of the unions  though number by the respondent-union .

facts.text: Labour Appellate Tribunal heard appeals together and set aside awards, remanded.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually it set aside the award and remanded the matter for early hearing in the light of the observations made by it.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then came to this Court and was granted special leave and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Appellant contended workmen of contractors were not workmen of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the second point arose on the stand taken by the appellant that the workmen of the companytractors were number the workmen of the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court held industrial court had jurisdiction as dispute linked to Sch. II items.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, a dispute relating to companytract labour if it is to be referred under s. 73A by a registered union can only be referred to an industrial companyrt as it immediately raises matters companytained in items  2 ,  9  and  10  of Sch.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no contravention of Art. 19(1)(g) by including mode of employment in industrial matter.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that this companytention also fails.

facts.text: Sections 3(13) and 3(14) define employee and employer to include contract labour workers.

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 3 13  defines the word employee and includes in it any person employed by a companytractor to do any work for him in the execution of a companytract with an employer within the meaning of sub-cl.  e  of cl.  14 .

facts.text: Unions raised question of permanent increase in number of persons employed.

anchor.surface_text: In particular, we may point out that in their petitions the unions had raised at least the question as to the permanent increase in the number of persons employed

issues.text: whether the industrial court had jurisdiction to decide the dispute as the matter was covered by item 6 of Sch. III of the Act, which is within the exclusive jurisdiction of a labour court

anchor.surface_text: namely,  i  that the industrial court had no jurisdiction to decide the dispute as the matter was covered by item  6  of Sch. III of the Act, which is within the exclusive jurisdiction of a labour court and  ii  that any award directing abolition of contract labour would contravene the fundamental right of the appellant to carry on business under Art. 19 1  g  of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether any award directing abolition of contract labour would contravene the fundamental right of the appellant to carry on business under Art. 19(1)(g) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: contravene the fundamental right of the appellant to carry on business under Art. 19 1  g  of the Constitution. The industrial court decided both the points against the appellant on the question of jurisdiction it held that the matter was covered by item  2  of Sch. 11 of the Act and therefore the industrial court would have jurisdiction, and on the second point it held that there was no contravention of the fundamental right conferred on the appellant under Art. 19 1  g .

issues.text: whether the definition of industrial matter under s. 3(18) including mode of employment contravenes Art. 19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: He bases his argument in this behalf on s. 3 18 , which defines an industrial matter as meaning any matter relating to employment, work, wages, hours of work, privileges, rights or duties of employers or employees, or the mode, terms and conditions of employment. Mr. Pathak urges that the definition of industrial matter contravenes the fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19 1  g , when it provides that the mode of employment is also included within it.

issues.text: whether contract labour are employees of the principal employer under ss. 3(13) and 3(14)

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 3 13  defines the word employee and includes in it any person employed by a contractor to do any work for him in the execution of a contract with an employer within the meaning of sub-cl.  e  of cl.  14 . Sec. 3 14  defines the word employer in an inclusive manner and includes where the owner of any undertaking in the course of or for the purpose of conducting the undertaking contracts with any person for the execution by or under the contractor of the whole or any part of any work which is ordinarily part of the undertaking, the owner of the undertaking.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually it set aside the award and remanded the matter for early hearing in the light of the observations made by it.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t it is required to be referred to the labour companyrt for its decision. Sec. 78 of the Act provides for jurisdiction of labour companyrts and matter

arguments.court_reasoning: Jurisdiction under s.73A for Sch. II matters prevails regardless of Sch. III scope

arguments.claim: Whether restriction reasonable depends on facts of each case; outside appellate power

anchor.surface_text: On the question of contravention of the, fundamental right, the appellate tribunal took the view that the question whether the restriction imposed was reasonable depended upon the facts of each case and therefore was a matter outside its power as a court of appeal It then considered the merits of the matter and came to the conclusion that the approach of the industrial court to the questions raised before it was not correct and therefore it found it difficult to support the award.

arguments.claim: Employment in item 6 Sch. III is wide, includes abolition of contract labour

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak contends that item  6  of Sch. III speaks of employment and includes in it two matters which might otherwise not have been thought to be included in it. Therefore, according to him, employment as used in item  6  is wider than the two matters included in it and the question whether contract labour should be employed or not would be a matter of employment within the meaning of that word in item  6  of Sch. 111.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t it is required to be referred to the labour companyrt for its decision. Sec. 78 of the Act provides for jurisdiction of labour companyrts and matter

arguments.court_reasoning: Irrelevant if covered by Sch. II; union ref to industrial court

arguments.claim: Under ss.71,72 jurisdiction concurrent for govt refs; s.73A union ref to industrial court except where exclusively labour court; s.78 labour courts exclude Sch. II; thus Sch. II matters to industrial court

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of the Act shows that under ss. 71 and 72 the jurisdiction of a labour court and an industrial court is concurrent with respect to any matters which the State Government may deem fit to refer to them but under s. 73A reference by a registered union... Sec. 78 of the Act provides for jurisdiction of labour courts and matters specified in Sch. 11 are not within their ordinary jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Contract labour abolition raises Sch. II items 2 (permanent increase), 9 (wages/mode), 10 (hours/rest); inextricably mixed; must go to industrial court under s.73A

anchor.surface_text: Now the question whether contract labour should be abolished... immediately raises questions relating to permanent increase in the number of persons employed, their wages including the period and mode of payment, hours of work and rest intervals, which are items  2 ,  9  and  10  of Sch. ... Therefore, a dispute relating to contract labour if it is to be referred under s. 73A by a registered union can only be referred to an industrial court as it immediately raises matters contained in items  2 ,  9  and  10  of Sch.

arguments.claim: Matters like permanent increase, wages etc. not really disputed by appellant

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak urges however that matters relating to permanent increase in the number of persons employed due to the abolition of contract labour, their wages, hours of work and rest intervals were not really disputed at all by the appellant.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: appears that in the written-statements of the appellant, these points were number raised but the decision of the appellate tribunal shows that one of

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant's contention that workmen not employees raises those disputes; unions raised permanent increase

arguments.claim: Definition of industrial matter s.3(18) including mode of employment contravenes Art.19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: He bases his argument in this behalf on s. 3 18 , which defines an industrial matter as meaning any matter relating to employment, work, wages, hours of work, privileges, rights or duties of employers or employees, or the mode, terms and conditions of employment. Mr. Pathak urges that the definition of industrial matter contravenes the fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19 1  g , when it provides that the mode of employment is also included within it. Reference is also made to s. 3 17  which defines an industrial dispute as any dispute or difference

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e matters so inextricably mixed up with the question relating to abolition of companytract labour that they must be held to be in dispute as soon as t

arguments.court_reasoning: Quasi-judicial adjudication on reasonableness per case; not unreasonable restriction

arguments.claim: Power to industrial court on mode of employment interferes with right to carry on trade; contravenes Art.19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak therefore urges that reading the two definitions together the industrial court is given the power to decide disputes as to the mode of employment and that contravenes the fundamental right guaranteed under Art. 19 1  g , for it enables an industrial court to adjudicate on the mode of employment and thus interfere with the right of the employer to carry on his trade as he likes subject to reasonable restrictions.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: f its labour force . The companytention about jurisdiction must therefore be rejected. This brings us to the second companytention raised by Mr. Patha

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal assesses reasonableness after hearing parties; judicial/quasi-judicial not unconstitutional restriction

arguments.claim: Quasi-judicial tribunal decides mode reasonableness case-by-case after hearing; abolition only if reasonable; not unreasonable restriction on Art.19(1)(g)

anchor.surface_text: Now assuming that the mode of employment used in s. 3 18  includes such questions as abolition of contract labour, the question would still be whether a provision which enables an industrial court to adjudicate on the question whether contract- tract labour should or should not be abolished is an unreasonable restriction on the employers right to carry on his trade. We cannot see how the fact that power is given to the industrial court, which is a quasi-judicial tribunal to decide whether contract labour should be abolished or not would make the definition of industrial matter in so far as it refers to the mode of employment, an unreasonable restriction on the fundamental, right of the employer to carry on trade.

arguments.claim: Contract labour are employees of mills under ss.3(13),3(14); no need to abolish, just equalize terms

anchor.surface_text: Finally, Mr. Pathak draws our attention to ss. 3 13  and 3 14  of the Act and submits that the appellant never said that contract labour employed in its mills was not in its employment. Sec. 3 13  defines the word employee and includes in it any person employed by a contractor to do any work for him in the execution of a contract with an employer within the meaning of sub-cl.  e  of cl.  14 . Sec. 3 14  defines the word employer in an inclusive manner and in- cludes where the owner of any undertaking in the course of or for the purpose of conducting the undertaking contracts with any person for the execution by or under the contractor of the whole or any part of any work which is ordinarily part of the undertaking, the owner of the undertaking.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pose of companyducting the undertaking companytracts with any person for the execution by or under the companytractor of the whole or any part of any

arguments.court_reasoning: Not raised before lower courts; may consider on remand if assures equal terms

holdings.text: we are of opinion that the industrial court had jurisdiction to deal with the matter

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the industrial court had jurisdiction to deal with the matter. In particular, we may point out that in their petitions the unions had raised at least the question as to the permanent increase in the number of persons employed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute on abolition of contract labour inextricably linked to Sch. II items 2, 9, 10 (permanent increase, wages/mode, hours/rest); s.73A references by union to industrial court for Sch. II matters

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that this contention also fails

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that this contention also fails. Finally, Mr. Pathak draws our attention to ss. 3 13 and 3 14 of the Act and submits that the appellant never said that contract labour employed in its mills was not in its employment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.3(18) including mode of employment not unreasonable restriction under Art.19(1)(g) as decided case-by-case by quasi-judicial industrial court after hearing parties on reasonableness

holdings.text: it cannot be said that by providing in s. 3 18 that an industrial matter includes also the mode of employment, there is any contravention of the fundamental right of the employer to carry on trade

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances it cannot be said that by providing in s. 3 18 that an industrial matter includes also the mode of employment, there is any contravention of the fundamental right of the employer to carry on trade. If the argument on behalf of the appellant were to be accepted it would mean that judicial and quasi-judicial decisions could be unreasonable restrictions on fundamental rights and this the Constitution does not envisage at all.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial determination of reasonableness of mode of employment does not constitute unreasonable restriction; judicial/quasi-judicial decisions cannot be deemed unreasonable per se

holdings.text: when the matter goes back before the industrial court as directed by the appellate tribunal, the industrial court may take this submission of the appellant into account and may consider whether it is necessary to abolish the contract system, provided the appellant is able to assure the industrial court that employees of the contractors who are deemed to be its employees within the meaning of s. 3 13 and s. 3 14 would have the full benefit of the same terms and conditions of service as its comparable direct employees

anchor.surface_text: All that we need therefore say is that when the matter goes back before the industrial court as directed by the appellate tribunal, the industrial court may take this submission of the appellant into account and may consider whether it is necessary to abolish the contract system, provided the appellant is able to assure the industrial court that employees of the contractors who are deemed to be its employees within the meaning of s. 3 13 and s. 3 14 would have the full benefit of the same terms and conditions of service as its comparable direct employees.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Point not contested before lower courts; permissible for industrial court to consider on remand if contractor employees assured equal terms

justification_sets.label: Section 73A Bombay Industrial Relations Act 1947 support

anchor.surface_text: The contention about jurisdiction must therefore be rejected. This brings us to the second contention raised by Mr. Pathak. He bases his argument in this behalf on s. 3(18), which defines an industrial matter as meaning any matter relating to employment, work, wages, hours of work, privileges, rights or duties of employers or employees, or the mode, terms and conditions of employment.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the industrial court had jurisdiction to deal with the matter. In particular, we may point out that in their petitions the unions had raised at least the question as to the permanent increase in the number of persons employed

The contention about jurisdiction must therefore be rejected. This brings us to the second contention raised by Mr. Pathak. He bases his argument in this behalf on s. 3(18), which defines an industrial matter as meaning any matter relating to employment, work, wages, hours of work, privileges, rights or duties of employers or employees, or the mode, terms and conditions of employment.

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances it cannot be said that by providing in s. 3 18 that an industrial matter includes also the mode of employment, there is any contravention of the fundamental right of the employer to carry on trade. If the argument on behalf of the appellant were to be accepted it would mean that judicial and quasi-judicial decisions could be unreasonable restrictions on fundamental rights and this the Constitution does not envisage at all.

The contention about jurisdiction must therefore be rejected. This brings us to the second contention raised by Mr. Pathak. He bases his argument in this behalf on s. 3(18), which defines an industrial matter as meaning any matter relating to employment, work, wages, hours of work, privileges, rights or duties of employers or employees, or the mode, terms and conditions of employment.

anchor.surface_text: All that we need therefore say is that when the matter goes back before the industrial court as directed by the appellate tribunal, the industrial court may take this submission of the appellant into account and may consider whether it is necessary to abolish the contract system, provided the appellant is able to assure the industrial court that employees of the contractors who are deemed to be its employees within the meaning of s. 3 13 and s. 3 14 would have the full benefit of the same terms and conditions of service as its comparable direct employees.
